Liked this puzzle a lot. There are actually 4 ways to find "inside" in the circled letters -- the left half, the right half (which Caitlin mentioned), the top half, and the bottom half (which Anita mentioned below). 2 are forwards and two are backwards. Now I'm wondering if connecting the circled letters makes a pictures. It looks a bit like the crumpled shirt on the floor that I put on inside out and backwards this morning.

I finished the puzzle, and presumably I'm supposed add, or subtract, or whatever to the circles.  Do I take something out? Add slashes?  I don't get it.  I see that by removing a letter, the backward clues work, but how do I express that in the puzzle?  Leave the circles blank?  Leave a blank a letter and add a blank in the circles?

> separated by a backslash

no, no, NO! That is not what '/' is! That's a slash. A normal punctuation mark. '\' is a backslash, used primarily in specific computing contexts, but for some reason a LOT of people get this wrong.

Well, I was prepared to complain that if you're going to go the cheeky phonetic route, "Ahnuld" would be the answer and "Ahnold" is just half----- and wrong.  But I checked Ngram and found the Old version is more prevalent, somehow.

Anyway, this was fun to do and the theme was helpful.  I figured the circled letters would reassemble to something interesting but I was too lazy to get it until I read the column.  :)

Very impressive construction that didn't chintz on wit or fun.  Thanks.

The question is this:  where would you draw the line for a clue like 1D?  Isn't the continuum from "precise" to "hilariously worded" to "unacceptable" is a very hard one to make precise boundaries? On?

Isn't that what makes this forum such a riot?

So much to enjoy in this one, incredible craftsmanship and a fun fill, at least for me.

I don't understand the problem with AHNOLD. 

The clue is heavy slang. AHNOLD  is a well-known nickname for the man, perhaps made famous, for me, anyway, by Dana and Kevin on SNL.

Anyway, good puzzle, fun gimmick. Enjoyable Sunday.

Slowed down also by US usage, which is obviously inevitable, like Sun Devils, and BARCADES,  which I looked up; but  UTE, EBT, DNC, JAVA for mud, DUPED for got good - I didn't find those.

As it turned out, I solved it like a themeless puzzle, then went back to admire the feat Adam and Rebecca performed.  It kind of mind-blowing, actually.

Really amazing piece of construction - just well above my pay grade. I did figure out the trick but still got stuck in more than a few places. Actually surprised that everyone else was able to work this one out. 

Maybe time to return my home planet. 

See you tomorrow.

I can appreciate how difficult AHNOLD must have been for international solvers.  For me, the clue was pretty much a giveaway, but I left the H blank just in case.  

sEAVIES, must have looked odd, though.  Do many solvers not look at the crosses?  If I saw something like sEAVIES, I would try to make sense of it, and if I couldn't I would recheck the crosses.  I'm really just curious about solving styles and wonder if the rush to get a good completion time leads to errors that then get blamed on the puzzle.

I did this puzzle after getting back to my hotel in Queens after attending the wedding of the daughter of my best friend of 50 some years.  I appreciated that it was cleverly constructed, yet not too strenuous, and had some wit about it.  I can picture someone calling someone else a SPATULA, and when met with a look of bewilderment, telling them ‚Äúbecause you‚Äôre a flipping tool.‚Äù 

I wonder if I‚Äôm a TEASNOB because I like a cup of Darjeeling in the morning.

Okay.  So I, whose brain inexplicably delights in palindromes and semordnilaps, most certainly reveled in this theme and in uncovering every theme answer.  Rebecca and Adam, you had me from NETIPOT/TOPTEN to ROMAINE/ENAMOR.  Full stop, end of story.

Well no, not end of story.  After reading the constructor notes, add ‚Äúastonished‚Äù to ‚Äúdelighted‚Äù:

First, Rebecca wanted to make a theme based on ‚Äúsemipermeable membrane‚Äù!  Amazing.

Second, Adam took Rebecca‚Äôs concept ‚Äì having words morph into other words, but with something left out ‚Äì and in only ‚Äúa few more minutes‚Äù came up with today‚Äôs less arcane version, going from ‚Äúsemipermeable membrane‚Äù to the marvelous INSIDE OUT AND BACKWARDS (both 21 letters, btw), with the answers fitting Rebecca‚Äôs concept. What a brilliant  leap, and made so quickly!  Astounding.

Third, the nuts and bolts performed by this duo.  Finding words that can do what these theme answers do, with those words containing letters that spell ‚ÄúINSIDE‚Äù in the circles, in order ‚Äì twice!  Boggling.

The miracle of crosswords.  I come to a box of empty squares, and by the time I leave I‚Äôm agape and enchanted.  Wow, Rebecca and Adam, and thank you!
‚ÄòThe BEEB‚Äô is very much a British channel, not an English one. Sloppy.
Caitlin is a psychic.  1D indeed held a wrong square for me.   I didn't get the music because of the spelling aHnold instead of aRnold.    Oh well, that's the way the Oreo crumbles sometimes.

I‚Äôm just gonna get to the heart 
of what matters most, 
and I think I speak for
absolutely everyone, everywhere- 


Melt one stick of butter. 
Mix with 2 cups crushed Oreos.
Smash into a pie pan to make a crust.
Put in freezer for 3 minutes to solidify.

Pour chocolate pudding in a 1/2 inch layer on the crust.

Mix 2 cups whipped cream with 1/2 cup chocolate pudding and pour on top of pudding.

Mix about a cup of whipped cream with 10 crushed Oreos, and plop over the cream/pudding layer.

Sprinkle with a crushed Oreo.

Chill.

Oreo pie.
Eat the whole thing.
Regret nothing.

That said, I still found the theme and many of the thematic entries somehow unsatisfying. WASPI(E)R especially troubled me, in part because RIPS appears at 5D (though its clue there was chosen to differ from what the saw does). But beyond that, the initialism WASP can be considered derogatory. As that entry began to reveal itself, I found myself hoping it wasn't going to be "waspish". And it wasn't, but WASPIER was just as troubling. Surprised that the editors didn't ask for that thematic entry to be replaced.

I wonder if the EMUs have signified their agreement with me, by flagging my post as concerning? In any case, the post has not appeared.

In other matters, I think AHNOLD is exactly correct for that clue---not to mention required for 19A.

I have no beef with AHNOLD, I thought SEACRAB was a stretch and I‚Äôve never heard of a BARCADE, nor do I want to go to one. All that noise and flashing lights plus alcohol, I‚Äôd be a HOTMESS. Very fun puzzle!

But my last letter was at square 89, where I had no idea of either abbreviation ... so looked up the food assistance one to get my gold star.

After the dust settled I enjoyed seeing how the theme worked in each case. "Backwards" was clear, but I still don't get why anything might be called "inside out". (Explanations welcome.)

And finally, NETIPOT is a rather specialized item, with the I being troublesome for me since it wasn't part of the backwards TOPTEN answer. In the end I wouldn't say it was unfair, just not easy, and not exactly in the spirit of "of course" that we often feel when we finally solve a difficult clue.

That was a fun challenge.

DNC stands for "Democratic National Committee" (often called the DEMS), whose symbol is the donkey (as the elephant is the symbol of the Republicans or RNC).

EBT stands for Electronic Benefits Transfer, a credit card-like item that can be used (by the underprivileged) to buy food and other things deemed necessities by the powers that be.

DUPED is slang for tricked or deceived, as in "I was duped into buying a counterfeit."  DUPE can also be shorthand for "duplicate":  "I can get you a DUPE of that document."

@Xword Junkie The initialism for the Italian slur is an incorrect folk etymology. The word derives from southern Italian dialect. From Wikipedia: The Merriam-Webster dictionary states wop's first known use was in the United States in 1908, and that it originates from the Southern Italian dialectal term guappo, roughly meaning "dandy", or "swaggerer", derived from the Spanish term guapo, meaning "good-looking", "dandy", from Latin vappa for "sour wine", also "worthless fellow". In Neapolitan and other Southern Italo-Romance varieties, guappo is pronounced roughly as wahp-po. As word-final vowels in Southern Italian varieties are often realized as /…ô/, guappo would often sound closer to wahpp to anglophones. Guappo historically refers to a type of flashy, boisterous, swaggering, dandy-like man.[6] The word eventually became associated with members of the Camorra and has often been used in the Naples area as a friendly or humorous term of address among men. The word likely transformed into the slur "(deleted)" following the arrival of poor Italian immigrants into the United States. The term guappo was especially used by older Italian immigrant males to refer to the younger Italian male immigrants arriving in America. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wop

@Lynn  Interesting the comments today about WASP being derogatory. Learning that I was a WASP was very educational and important in my life. For one thing, I learned that there were aspects to life I didn't have to deal with that my non-WASP friends did. All my religious holidays were recognized by the public schools, for instance--every one of them. And our beliefs were encoded into the blue laws--no alcohol sold on Sundays. There was one Catholic family on our suburban block and they were definitely looked at with suspicion because they could gamble (Bingo) and drink wine (instead of Welch's Grape Juice at communion). 

I understood something about racism and racial discrimination and knew we were a pro-integration family, but had assumed that the Anglo-Saxon Protestant cultural practices and beliefs I had grown up with were comfortable for everyone. Because, for the most part, I did not recognize them as a set of practices and beliefs. Recognizing this, and learning that there were others, was crucial to understanding a lot of things in the world that had been invisible to me.
